benefits.title: Biological Properties of Curcumin-Cellular and Molecular Mechanisms of Action
benefits.summary: Curcumin exhibits beneficial effects on health, including anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, anticarcinogenic, antiviral, and antiinfectious activities, as well as wound healing and detoxifying properties.
benefits.journal: Critical Reviews in Food Science and Nutrition

benefits.title: Curcumin nanoformulations: a future nanomedicine for cancer.
benefits.summary: Curcumin modulates intracellular signaling pathways controlling cancer cell growth, inflammation, invasion, and apoptosis, revealing its anticancer potential.

benefits.title: Curcumin and its Derivatives: Their Application in Neuropharmacology and Neuroscience in the 21st Century
benefits.summary: Curcumin has therapeutic benefits for neurodegenerative diseases like Alzheimer's and Parkinson's diseases, and malignancy, via regulation of transcription factors, cytokines, and enzymes associated with NFÎ± B activity.

benefits.title: Therapeutic Applications of Curcumin Nanoformulations
benefits.summary: Curcumin has exhibited excellent therapeutic benefits in various diseases due to its anti-oxidant and anti-inflammatory properties.

benefits.title: Bioactivity, Health Benefits, and Related Molecular Mechanisms of Curcumin: Current Progress, Challenges, and Perspectives
benefits.summary: Curcumin has protective or preventive effects on cancers, diabetes, liver, nervous system, and cardiovascular systems, and is a promising ingredient in novel functional foods.

benefits.title: Why it is necessary to translate curcumin into clinical practice for the prevention and treatment of metabolic syndrome?
benefits.summary: Curcumin has anticancer, anti-inflammatory, antioxidant, antithrombotic, antiatherosclerotic, cardioprotective, neuroprotective, memory enhancing, and other properties.

benefits.title: Skin regenerative potentials of curcumin
benefits.summary: Curcumin is beneficial in treating various disorders, including skin diseases, by quenching free radicals, reducing inflammation, and modulating phase II detoxification enzymes.

benefits.title: Recent advances in colloidal delivery systems for nutraceuticals: A case study - Delivery by Design of curcumin.
benefits.summary: Curcumin has potential biological benefits including antioxidant, antimicrobial, anti-inflammatory, and anti-cancer activity.
benefits.journal: Journal of colloid and interface science

benefits.title: Benefits of curcumin in brain disorders
benefits.summary: Curcumin has been reported to have benefits in neurological diseases like Alzheimer's, Parkinson's, Multiple Sclerosis, Huntington's, Prions, stroke, Down's syndrome, autism, and ALS.

benefits.title: Curcumin and its different forms: A review on fish nutrition
benefits.summary: Curcumin has antioxidant, anti-inflammatory, antimicrobial, chemoprotective, hepatoprotective, anti-cancer, gastroprotective, and neuroprotective properties, and is involved in growth promotion.

side effects.title: Curcumin inhibits the side population (SP) phenotype of the rat C6 glioma cell line: towards targeting of cancer stem cells with phytochemicals.
side effects.summary: Curcumin treatment decreases the side population (SP) of rat C6 glioma cells, suggesting potential targeting of cancer stem cells.

side effects.title: Curcumin and cancer biology: Focusing regulatory effects in different signalling pathways
side effects.summary: Curcumin alters the development of cancer by regulating microRNA expression and modifying signaling pathways like Akt, Bcl-2, PTEN, p53, Notch, and Erbb.

side effects.title: Curcumin: A potentially powerful tool to reverse cisplatin‐induced toxicity
side effects.summary: Curcumin has been used to decrease cisplatin-induced side effects like ototoxicity, nephrotoxicity, and neurotoxicity.

side effects.title: Curcumin may impair iron status when fed to mice for six months
side effects.summary: Long-term curcumin supplementation may aggravate iron deficiency when fed to mice for six months.

side effects.title: Curcumin and its derivatives in cancer therapy: Potentiating antitumor activity of cisplatin and reducing side effects.
side effects.summary: Curcumin can reduce the hepatoxicity, neurotoxicity, renal toxicity, ototoxicity, and cardiotoxicity caused by cisplatin.

side effects.title: Advances in research on the anti-tumor effect of curcumin
side effects.summary: Curcumin can inhibit tumor cell proliferation and induce apoptosis without negative side effects.

side effects.title: The clinical applications of curcumin: current state and the future.
side effects.summary: Curcumin has minor gastrointestinal side effects up to a dosage of 8 grams for 3 months.

side effects.title: Side Effects of Curcumin: Epigenetic and Antiproliferative Implications for Normal Dermal Fibroblast and Breast Cancer Cells
side effects.summary: Curcumin administration can potentially confer benefits, but high doses may be toxic, making its use as a dietary supplement or in cancer therapies a double edge.

side effects.title: Curcumin in Combination with Piperine Suppresses Osteoclastogenesis In Vitro.
side effects.summary: Curcumin combined with piperine suppressed osteoclastogenesis in vitro without causing cytotoxic effects in periodontal ligament cells.

side effects.title: Curcumin: A review of anti-cancer properties and therapeutic activity in head and neck squamous cell carcinoma
side effects.summary: Curcumin is nontoxic and has therapeutic properties such as anti-oxidant, analgesic, anti-inflammatory, and antiseptic activity.

dosage.title: Efficacy of curcumin, and a saffron/curcumin combination for the treatment of major depression: A randomised, double-blind, placebo-controlled study.
dosage.summary: Low-dose curcumin extract (250mg b.i.d.) and high-dose curcumin extract (500mg b.i.d.) were effective in reducing depressive and anxiolytic symptoms in people with major depressive disorder.

dosage.title: Phytosomal curcumin: A review of pharmacokinetic, experimental and clinical studies.
dosage.summary: Curcumin is safe at dosages as high as 8g per day, but its bioavailability is reduced due to its low solubility in water and rapid metabolism.

dosage.title: Curcumin for the treatment of major depression: a randomised, double-blind, placebo controlled study.
dosage.summary: Curcumin (500 mg twice daily) was effective in improving mood-related symptoms in individuals with major depressive disorder.

dosage.title: Effect of Different Curcuminoid Supplement Dosages on Total In Vivo Antioxidant Capacity and Cholesterol Levels of Healthy Human Subjects
dosage.summary: Curcumin dosage at 500 mg/day is more effective than 6 g for reducing serum cholesterol and triglyceride levels.

dosage.title: Oral intake of curcumin markedly activated CYP 3A4: in vivo and ex-vivo studies
dosage.summary: Oral intake of curcumin at 50 and 100 mg/kg significantly decreased the bioavailability of everolimus by 70.6% and 71.5%, respectively.

dosage.title: Combined Treatment of Curcumin and Small Molecule Inhibitors Suppresses Proliferation of A549 and H1299 Human Non‐Small‐Cell Lung Cancer Cells
dosage.summary: A low dosage of curcumin (5-10 Î14m) combined with low concentrations of small molecule inhibitors increased growth inhibition in human non-small cell lung cancer cells.

dosage.title: Drug delivery systems for overcoming the bioavailability of curcumin: not only the nanoparticle matters.
dosage.summary: Curcumin is safe even at dosages as high as 12 g/day in humans.

dosage.title: Effect of different curcumin dosages on human gall bladder.
dosage.summary: The dosage of curcumin capable of producing a 50% contraction of the gall bladder was 40 mg.
dosage.journal: Asia Pacific journal of clinical nutrition

dosage.title: A Nutraceutical approach to enhance Reproductive longevity and Ovarian health using Curcuma longa in wistar Rats
dosage.summary: Curcumin dosages in this study were 100 mg/kg body weight, 200 mg/kg body weight, and 400 mg/kg body weight.
dosage.journal: Research Journal of Pharmacy and Technology

dosage.title: Metabolism of curcumin--studies with [3H]curcumin.
dosage.summary: The dosage of curcumin in this study was 400, 80, or 10 mg, with most of the label excreted within 72 hours.
